thread.title: USC: Smith helps Trojans beat No. 3 Utah
thread.title_full: USC: Smith helps Trojans beat No. 3 Utah - Press Enterprise

author: MICHAEL LEV
title: USC: Smith helps Trojans beat No. 3 Utah
text:
BY MICHAEL LEV / STAFF WRITER
Published: Oct. 24, 2015 Updated: Oct. 25, 2015 8:35 a.m. LOS ANGELES â" Cameron Smith was the last Trojan to enter the USC locker room Saturday night at the Coliseum.
The freshman linebacker had business to attend to on the field.
After intercepting three passes against No.3 Utah â" igniting and inspiring the Trojansâ badly needed 42-24 victory over the Utes â" Smith became the unlikely leader of the Trojan Marching Band.
Outside the locker room, USC quarterback Cody Kessler intercepted Smith. The senior gave the freshman a well-earned hug.
âHe deserves it,â Kessler said moments later. âThose picks â" that won us the game tonight.â
They might have saved the Trojansâ season, such as it is.
At 4-3 overall, USC is out of the running for the College Football Playoff. But at 2-2 in the conference â" with wins over Utah and Arizona State â" the Trojans remain alive for the Pac-12 South title.
Considering all theyâve been through â" a midseason coaching change, three losses in four games and an injury list thatâs growing by the week â" thatâs something.
âItâs been tough,â Kessler said. âThese guys have been pushed to the limit. Thank God for this guy.â
Kessler was referring to interim coach Clay Helton, who has preached positivity and togetherness since taking over for the fired Steve Sarkisian earlier this month. Helton deferred the credit.
âI want to thank these players,â Helton said. âUnbelievable resiliency these guys have. They amaze me as a coach.â
Although USC was favored over Utah (6-1, 3-1), the Trojans did not enter Saturday with momentum on their side. Not only had they lost two games in a row, but they had lost their last two games at home.
USC seemed to be headed down that same dark alley when Utah took a 14-7 lead late in the first quarter. But early in the second, the tenor of the game â" and the season â" changed.
On third-and-3 from the Utah 42-yard line, Smith stepped into the path of Travis Wilsonâs pass intended for tailback Devontae Booker.
âWe needed a spark,â Helton said, âand he gave it to us.â
Smith returned the ball 41 yards to the Utesâ 4. Four plays later, fullback Soma Vainuku dove over the goal line to tie the score at 14.
After Ronald Jones IIâs 18-yard touchdown run gave USC a 21-14 lead, Utah got the ball back with 3:31 left in the first half. The Utes advanced from their 11 to the Trojansâ 45 and faced fourth-and-2 with 1:20 remaining.
